abstractText: Molecular platinum fluorides PtF<sub>n</sub> , n=1-6, are prepared by two different routes, photo-initiated fluorine elimination from PtF<sub>6</sub> embedded in solid noble-gas matrices, and the reaction of elemental fluorine with laser-ablated platinum atoms. IR spectra of the reaction products isolated in rare-gas matrices under cryogenic conditions provide, for the first time, experimental vibrational frequencies of molecular PtF<sub>3</sub> , PtF<sub>4</sub> and PtF<sub>5</sub> . Photolysis of PtF<sub>6</sub> enabled a highly efficient and almost quantitative formation of molecular PtF<sub>4</sub> , whereas both PtF<sub>5</sub> and PtF<sub>3</sub> were formed simultaneously by subsequent UV irradiation of PtF<sub>4</sub> . The vibrational spectra of these molecular platinum fluorides were assigned with the help of one- and two-component quasirelativistic DFT computation to account for scalar relativistic and spin-orbit coupling effects. Competing Jahn-Teller and spin-orbit coupling effects result in a magnetic bistability of PtF<sub>4</sub> , for which a spin-triplet (<sup>3</sup> B<sub>2g</sub> , D<sub>2h</sub> ) coexists with an electronic singlet state (<sup>1</sup> A<sub>1g</sub> , D<sub>4h</sub> ) in solid neon matrices.
